author: sky.cactus
content: I think it is important that all possibly relevant data is exposed to apps.  As <@555483069038198827> said above, even if most apps don't use it we should support well designed apps who want to provide more complex safety guarantees.

author: sky.cactus
content: We can also offer users some simplicity stuff like what <@425279588009246720> suggested above.

author: sky.cactus
content: This means we either need to provide a public endpoint on the consensus client, or we need to route this information through the execution client (even though the execution client won't use it).

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm fine with either, though if we take the proxied approach I think it should be a transparent proxy solely for providing a single host/port for users to connect to, but we shouldn't require that the execution client actually understand the data it is proxying.

author: sky.cactus
content: As mentioned above, we don't want every change in data provided by the consensus client to require execution clients to do engineering work.

author: sky.cactus
content: Long term, I would rather see a new microservice added to the mix that provides a single RPC endpoint.  So an Ethereum installer package would include execution client, consensus client, UI server, and RPC server.

author: ajsutton
content: For the record, Infura is already exposing the beacon node rest api as a separate endpoint.

author: sky.cactus
content: The one that should be private?

author: ajsutton
content: The current beacon node REST API. There's only one currently. https://ethereum.github.io/beacon-APIs/

author: ajsutton
content: It's got the same security model as the eth1 JSON-RPC API.  You shouldn't expose it to the public without putting in place your own restrictions to prevent DOS attacks etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: DoS is the only bad thing someone can do with it?  They can't trick your consensus client into signing something bad?

author: ajsutton
content: No, the beacon node doesn't ever have access to validator keys.  And slashing protection should always prevent that even if for some reason you exposed your signer to the public (they could prevent you signing anything ever again which would be bad, but shouldn't be able to get you slashed).

author: ajsutton
content: The beacon API is just the beacon node, the validator client and any external signer is completely separate and not exposed by that API.

author: m.kalinin
content:
IMO, information from beacon chain about a number of confirmations contributed to a block is important for the user's RPC. And implementation of the proposal made by Dankrad is under consideration for the Merge scope. There is a JSON-RPC item in the Merge readiness checklist that implicitly covers this proposal along with other RPC updates.

I am leaning towards separation of responsibilities between consensus and execution layers in terms of providing an information about the state of the network. As it was mentioned above, it will allow us to expose more information from the consensus layer to the user's JSON-RPC without involving execution client updates as it would be if we take another path (propagating everything down to the execution layer).

As for the approach to user's lib implementations, web3 *may* query data from both endpoints, consensus and execution, and match the information before serving it to the user. `eth_getBlockByNumber` may have a new option for the block identifier e.g. "confirmed". Serving a request with this option web3 impl queries consensus layer in the first place to get the most recent block with e.g. `0.7` confirmation threshold (whatever is considered safe); then query execution layer to get the block information and respond to the user.

Late to the party again. All these points were mentioned above.

author: sky.cactus
content: Thinking more about the API, I think having them as separate endpoints is good because it means someone running their own consensus client but a third party execution client can trustlessly follow the correct chain at least.

author: sky.cactus
content: For end-users, I believe this results in a *slightly* lower trust setup than if you outsource both execution and consensus clients.
